Mixture Model.content: Probabilistic model that assumes that the data is generated from a mixture of several distributions, each representing a different subpopulation within the overall population.

MoE (Mixture of Experts).title: MoE (Mixture of Experts)
MoE (Mixture of Experts).content: ML architecture that utilizes multiple specialist models (experts) to handle different parts of the input space, coordinated by a gating mechanism that decides which expert to use for each input.

Model Compression.title: Model Compression
Model Compression.content: Techniques designed to reduce the size of a machine learning model without significantly sacrificing its accuracy.

Model Drift Minimization.title: Model Drift Minimization
Model Drift Minimization.content: Strategies and methodologies to ensure that a ML model remains accurate and relevant over time as the underlying data changes.

Model Drift.title: Model Drift
Model Drift.content: Change in the underlying data patterns that a ML model was trained on, leading to a decrease in the model's accuracy and effectiveness over time.

Model Garden.title: Model Garden
Model Garden.content: Centralized repository that houses a collection of pre-trained machine learning models designed to be easily accessible and reusable by developers and researchers.

Model Level.title: Model Level
Model Level.content: Abstraction layer at which an AI or ML model operates, focusing on the specific details and mechanics of the model's architecture and functioning.

Model Management.title: Model Management
Model Management.content: Practices and technologies used to handle various lifecycle stages of machine learning models including development, deployment, monitoring, and maintenance.

Model-Based Classifier.title: Model-Based Classifier
Model-Based Classifier.content: ML algorithm that uses a pre-defined statistical model to make predictions based on input data.

Motor Learning.title: Motor Learning
Motor Learning.content: Process by which robots or AI systems acquire, refine, and optimize motor skills through experience and practice.

Move 37.title: Move 37
Move 37.content: Pivotal move made by AlphaGo in its second game against Go champion Lee Sedol, which showcased the superior strategic capabilities of AI in the game of Go.

Multi-Token Prediction.title: Multi-Token Prediction
Multi-Token Prediction.content: AI technique used in NLP where a model generates multiple output tokens simultaneously, often improving coherence and speed compared to single-token generation methods.

Multi-headed Attention.title: Multi-headed Attention
Multi-headed Attention.content: Mechanism in neural networks that allows the model to jointly attend to information from different representation subspaces at different positions.

Multiagent.title: Multiagent
Multiagent.content: Multiple autonomous entities (agents) interacting in a shared environment, often with cooperative or competitive objectives.

Multimodal.title: Multimodal
Multimodal.content: AI systems or models that can process and understand information from multiple modalities, such as text, images, and sound.

NAS (Neural Architecture Search).title: NAS (Neural Architecture Search)
NAS (Neural Architecture Search).content: Automated process that designs optimal neural network architectures for specific tasks.

NHI (Non-Human Intelligence).title: NHI (Non-Human Intelligence)
NHI (Non-Human Intelligence).content: Intelligence systems that operate independently of human intelligence, encompassing a broad range of entities and origins, emphasizing capabilities that may surpass human cognitive processes.

NIAN (Needle in a Needlestack).title: NIAN (Needle in a Needlestack)
NIAN (Needle in a Needlestack).content: Idiom used to describe the difficulty of finding a specific piece of information or data within a vast, but homogeneous, dataset.

NLD (Neural Lie Detectors).title: NLD (Neural Lie Detectors)
NLD (Neural Lie Detectors).content: AI systems designed to identify dishonesty or inconsistencies in the outputs or decisions of other AI models by analyzing their responses or behavior.

NLP (Natural Language Processing).title: NLP (Natural Language Processing)
NLP (Natural Language Processing).content: Field of AI that focuses on the interaction between computers and humans through natural language.

NLP (Neuro-Linguistic Programming).title: NLP (Neuro-Linguistic Programming)
NLP (Neuro-Linguistic Programming).content: Techniques and methodologies for understanding and generating human language by computers.

NLU (Natural Language Understanding).title: NLU (Natural Language Understanding)
NLU (Natural Language Understanding).content: Subfield of NLP focused on enabling machines to understand and interpret human language in a way that is both meaningful and contextually relevant.

NPC (Non-Player Character).title: NPC (Non-Player Character)
NPC (Non-Player Character).content: Character in a virtual environment that operates under AI control, exhibiting behaviors or responses not directed by human players.

Naive Bayesian Model.title: Naive Bayesian Model
Naive Bayesian Model.content: Probabilistic classifier that assumes strong (naive) independence between the features of a dataset.

Narrow AI.title: Narrow AI
Narrow AI.content: Also known as Weak AI, refers to AI systems designed to perform a specific task or a narrow range of tasks with a high level of proficiency.

NeRF (Neural Radiance Fields).title: NeRF (Neural Radiance Fields)
NeRF (Neural Radiance Fields).content: Technique for creating high-quality 3D models from a set of 2D images using deep learning.

Negative Feedback.title: Negative Feedback
Negative Feedback.content: Control mechanism where the output of a system is fed back into the system in a way that counteracts fluctuations from a setpoint, thereby promoting stability.

Negative Utilitarianism.title: Negative Utilitarianism
Negative Utilitarianism.content: Ethical theory that prioritizes minimizing suffering and negative experiences over maximizing happiness and positive experiences.

Neural Network.title: Neural Network
Neural Network.content: Computing system designed to simulate the way human brains analyze and process information, using a network of interconnected nodes that work together to solve specific problems.

Neuroevolution.title: Neuroevolution
Neuroevolution.content: AI approach that uses evolutionary algorithms to develop and optimize artificial neural networks.

Neurogenesis.title: Neurogenesis
Neurogenesis.content: Process by which new neurons are formed in the brain.

Neuromorphic Chips.title: Neuromorphic Chips
Neuromorphic Chips.content: Specialized hardware designed to mimic the neural structures and functioning of the human brain to enhance computational efficiency and speed in processing AI algorithms.

Neurosymbolic AI.title: Neurosymbolic AI
Neurosymbolic AI.content: Integration of neural networks with symbolic AI to create systems that can both understand and manipulate symbols in a manner similar to human cognitive processes.

Ngram.title: Ngram
Ngram.content: Contiguous sequence of N items from a given sample of text or speech.

Noise.title: Noise
Noise.content: Irrelevant or meaningless data in a dataset or unwanted variations in signals that can interfere with the training and performance of AI models.

Non-Contrastive.title: Non-Contrastive
Non-Contrastive.content: ML approach that focuses on learning useful representations of data without explicitly contrasting positive examples against negative examples.

Numerical Processing.title: Numerical Processing
Numerical Processing.content: Algorithms and techniques for handling and analyzing numerical data to extract patterns, make predictions, or understand underlying trends.

OOMs (Orders of Magnitude).title: OOMs (Orders of Magnitude)
OOMs (Orders of Magnitude).content: Way to understand and compare quantities in terms of their scale or size, typically using powers of ten.

Object Detection.title: Object Detection
Object Detection.content: Computer vision technique that identifies and locates objects within an image or video frame.

Objective Function.title: Objective Function
Objective Function.content: Objective function used in ML which quantitatively defines the goal of an optimization problem by measuring the performance of a model or solution.

Observability.title: Observability
Observability.content: Capability to monitor and understand the internal states of an AI system through its outputs.

One-Shot Learning.title: One-Shot Learning
One-Shot Learning.content: ML technique where a model learns information about object categories from a single training example.

Ontology.title: Ontology
Ontology.content: Structured framework that categorizes and organizes information or data into a hierarchy of concepts and relationships, facilitating the sharing and reuse of knowledge across systems and domains.

Optimization Problem.title: Optimization Problem
Optimization Problem.content: Optimization problem in AI which involves finding the best solution from all feasible solutions, given a set of constraints and an objective to achieve or optimize.

Orchestration.title: Orchestration
Orchestration.content: Systematic coordination and management of various models, algorithms, and processes to efficiently execute complex tasks and workflows.

Overfitting.title: Overfitting
Overfitting.content: When a ML model learns the detail and noise in the training data to the extent that it negatively impacts the performance of the model on new data.

Overhang.title: Overhang
Overhang.content: Disparity between the minimum computation needed for a certain performance level and the actual computation used in training a model, often leading to superior model performance.

Overparameterized.title: Overparameterized
Overparameterized.content: ML model that has more parameters than the number of data points available for training.

P(Doom).title: P(Doom)
P(Doom).content: Probability of an existential catastrophe, often discussed within the context of AI safety and risk assessment.

P-hacking.title: P-hacking
P-hacking.content: Manipulation of data analysis to achieve statistically significant results, often by repeatedly testing different variables or subsets of data until desirable outcomes are found.

PFGM (Poisson Flow Generative Model).title: PFGM (Poisson Flow Generative Model)
PFGM (Poisson Flow Generative Model).content: Generative model that utilizes Poisson processes in its architecture to model and generate complex data distributions.

PPML (Privacy-Preserving Machine Learnin.title: PPML (Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning)
PPML (Privacy-Preserving Machine Learnin.content: Techniques that protect user data privacy during the machine learning process, without compromising the utility of the models.

PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization).title: PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization)
PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization).content: RL algorithm that aims to balance ease of implementation, sample efficiency, and reliable performance by using a simpler but effective update method for policy optimization.

PQ (Product Quantization).title: PQ (Product Quantization)
PQ (Product Quantization).content: Technique used in large-scale vector quantization for efficient similarity search and data compression by decomposing high-dimensional vectors into smaller sub-vectors and quantizing each sub-vector separately.

Panel-of-Experts.title: Panel-of-Experts
Panel-of-Experts.content: Decision-making system where multiple experts provide their opinions or solutions, and the consensus or most supported option is chosen.

Parallelism.title: Parallelism
Parallelism.content: Simultaneous execution of multiple processes or tasks to improve performance and efficiency.

Parameter Size.title: Parameter Size
Parameter Size.content: Count of individual weights in a ML model that are learned from data during training.

Parameter.title: Parameter
Parameter.content: Variable that is internal to the model and whose value is estimated from the training data.

Parameterized.title: Parameterized
Parameterized.content: Model or function in AI that utilizes parameters to make predictions or decisions.

Parametric Knowledge.title: Parametric Knowledge
Parametric Knowledge.content: Information and patterns encoded within the parameters of a machine learning model, which are learned during the training process.

Parametric Memory.title: Parametric Memory
Parametric Memory.content: Memory architecture where specific memories or facts are stored using parameterized models, often used to improve efficiency in storing and retrieving information in machine learning systems.

Path Integration.title: Path Integration
Path Integration.content: Computational process by which an agent estimates its current position based on its previous position and the path it has taken, using internal cues rather than external landmarks.

Perceptron.title: Perceptron
Perceptron.content: Model in neural networks designed to perform binary classification tasks by mimicking the decision-making process of a single neuron.

Perceptual Domain.title: Perceptual Domain
Perceptual Domain.content: Range of sensory inputs and interpretations that an AI system can process, akin to human perception systems such as vision, hearing, and touch.

Performance Degradation.title: Performance Degradation
Performance Degradation.content: Decline in the efficiency or effectiveness of an AI system over time or under specific conditions, leading to reduced accuracy, speed, or reliability.

Permutation.title: Permutation
Permutation.content: Arrangement of all or part of a set of objects in a specific order.

Perplexity.title: Perplexity
Perplexity.content: Measure used in language modeling to evaluate how well a model predicts a sample of text, quantifying the model's uncertainty in its predictions.

Persuasive System.title: Persuasive System
Persuasive System.content: Type of software designed to change a person's attitude or behavior through persuasion and social influence.

Phase Transition.title: Phase Transition
Phase Transition.content: Critical point where a small change in a parameter or condition causes a significant shift in the system's behavior or performance.

Point-wise Feedforward Network.title: Point-wise Feedforward Network
Point-wise Feedforward Network.content: Neural network layer that applies a series of linear and non-linear transformations to each position (or "point") in the input sequence independently.

Policy Gradient Algorithm.title: Policy Gradient Algorithm
Policy Gradient Algorithm.content: Type of RL algorithm that optimizes the policy directly by computing gradients of expected rewards with respect to policy parameters.

Policy Gradient.title: Policy Gradient
Policy Gradient.content: Class of algorithms in RL that optimizes the parameters of a policy directly through gradient ascent on expected future rewards.

Policy Parameters.title: Policy Parameters
Policy Parameters.content: Variables in a ML model, particularly in RL, that define the behavior of the policy by determining the actions an agent takes in different states.

Policy-Guided Diffusion.title: Policy-Guided Diffusion
Policy-Guided Diffusion.content: Method where a policy, typically learned via RL, guides the diffusion process in generating samples that conform to desired specifications or constraints.

Polymathic AI.title: Polymathic AI
Polymathic AI.content: AI systems that possess a wide range of skills and knowledge, enabling them to perform tasks across various domains, much like a human polymath.

Polymorphism.title: Polymorphism
Polymorphism.content: Ability of objects to take on many forms, allowing methods to perform differently based on the object that invokes them.

Positional Encoding.title: Positional Encoding
Positional Encoding.content: Technique used in neural network models, especially in transformers, to inject information about the order of tokens in the input sequence.

Post-Training.title: Post-Training
Post-Training.content: Techniques and adjustments applied to neural networks after their initial training phase to enhance performance, efficiency, or adaptability to new data or tasks.

Predictive Analytics.title: Predictive Analytics
Predictive Analytics.content: Using statistical techniques and algorithms to analyze historical data and make predictions about future events.

Preference Model.title: Preference Model
Preference Model.content: Computational framework used to predict and understand an individual's preferences, often applied in recommendation systems and decision-making processes.

Pretrained Model.title: Pretrained Model
Pretrained Model.content: ML model that has been previously trained on a large dataset and can be fine-tuned or used as is for similar tasks or applications.

Private Cloud Compute.title: Private Cloud Compute
Private Cloud Compute.content: Dedicated cloud infrastructure to provide cloud computing services exclusively to a single organization, ensuring enhanced control, privacy, and security.

Privileged Instructions.title: Privileged Instructions
Privileged Instructions.content: Commands in computing that can only be executed in a privileged mode, typically restricted to the operating system or other system-level software to manage hardware and critical operations securely.

Probabilistic Programming.title: Probabilistic Programming
Probabilistic Programming.content: Programming paradigm designed to handle uncertainty and probabilistic models, allowing for the creation of programs that can make inferences about data by incorporating statistical methods directly into the code.

Proliferation Problem.title: Proliferation Problem
Proliferation Problem.content: The issue of an overwhelming number of options or paths that an algorithm must consider, making computation impractically complex or resource-intensive.

Prompt Engineering.title: Prompt Engineering
Prompt Engineering.content: Process of carefully designing input prompts to elicit desired outputs from language models.

Prompt Injection.title: Prompt Injection
Prompt Injection.content: Technique used to manipulate or influence the behavior of AI models by inserting specific commands or cues into the input prompt.

Prompt.title: Prompt
Prompt.content: User-generated input or question designed to elicit a specific response or output from the model.

Promptocracy.title: Promptocracy
Promptocracy.content: Theoretical governance model where decision-making is guided by AI-generated prompts based on large datasets and probabilistic models.

Q-value.title: Q-value
Q-value.content: Measure used in RL to represent the expected future rewards that an agent can obtain, starting from a given state and choosing a particular action.

QA (Question Answering).title: QA (Question Answering)
QA (Question Answering).content: Field of natural language processing focused on building systems that automatically answer questions posed by humans in a natural language.

QA (Question-Answer).title: QA (Question-Answer)
QA (Question-Answer).content: Tools designed to provide precise answers to user queries by understanding and processing natural language inputs.

Quantization.title: Quantization
Quantization.content: Process of reducing the precision of the weights and activations in neural network models to decrease their memory and computational requirements.

Query.title: Query
Query.content: Request made to a data management system or AI model to retrieve information or execute a command based on specific criteria.

RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation).title: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)
RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation).content: Combines the retrieval of informative documents from a large corpus with the generative capabilities of neural models to enhance language model responses with real-world knowledge.

RBMs (Restricted Boltzmann Machines).title: RBMs (Restricted Boltzmann Machines)
RBMs (Restricted Boltzmann Machines).content: Type of generative stochastic artificial neural network that can learn a probability distribution over its set of inputs.

RFM (Robotics Foundational Model).title: RFM (Robotics Foundational Model)
RFM (Robotics Foundational Model).content: Base model designed to provide fundamental capabilities or understanding for the development of various robotic systems and applications.

RL (Reinforcement Learning).title: RL (Reinforcement Learning)
RL (Reinforcement Learning).content: Type of ML where an agent learns to make decisions by performing actions in an environment to achieve a goal, guided by rewards.

RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human.title: RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback)
RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human.content: Technique that combines reinforcement learning (RL) with human feedback to guide the learning process towards desired outcomes.

RLHF++.title: RLHF++
RLHF++.content: Advanced form of RLFH (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback), a technique used in ML to enhance model performance by incorporating human feedback into the training process.

RNN (Recurrent Neural Network).title: RNN (Recurrent Neural Network)
RNN (Recurrent Neural Network).content: Class of neural networks where connections between nodes form a directed graph along a temporal sequence, enabling them to exhibit temporal dynamic behavior for a sequence of inputs.

Random Forest.title: Random Forest
Random Forest.content: Robust ML algorithm that combines multiple decision trees to improve prediction accuracy and prevent overfitting.

Random Walk.title: Random Walk
Random Walk.content: Mathematical concept representing a path consisting of a succession of random steps on some mathematical space.

ReAct (Reason+Act).title: ReAct (Reason+Act)
ReAct (Reason+Act).content: AI framework for integrating reasoning and acting capabilities, enabling models to make decisions based on both logic and learned actions.

ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit).title: ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit)
ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit).content: Activation function commonly used in neural networks which outputs the input directly if it is positive, otherwise, it outputs zero.

Recommendation Systems.title: Recommendation Systems
Recommendation Systems.content: Algorithms designed to suggest relevant items to users (such as movies, books, products, etc.) based on their preferences and behaviors.

Recursive Self-Improvement.title: Recursive Self-Improvement
Recursive Self-Improvement.content: Process by which an AI system iteratively improves itself, enhancing its intelligence and capabilities without human intervention.

Red Teaming.title: Red Teaming
Red Teaming.content: Practice where a team independently challenges a system, project, or policy to identify vulnerabilities, improve security, and test the effectiveness of defenses, often applied in cybersecurity and, increasingly, in AI safety and ethics.

Reflective Programming.title: Reflective Programming
Reflective Programming.content: Programming paradigm that allows a program to inspect and modify its own structure and behavior at runtime.

Regime.title: Regime
Regime.content: Distinct operational or behavioral mode in which an AI system functions, characterized by specific patterns or properties of data, parameters, or algorithms.

Regression.title: Regression
Regression.content: Statistical method used in ML to predict a continuous outcome variable based on one or more predictor variables.

Regularization.title: Regularization
Regularization.content: Technique used in machine learning to reduce model overfitting by adding a penalty to the loss function based on the complexity of the model.

Rejection Sampling.title: Rejection Sampling
Rejection Sampling.content: Method used to generate samples from a probability distribution by proposing candidates from a simpler distribution and accepting or rejecting them based on a criterion related to the target distribution.

Reranking.title: Reranking
Reranking.content: Process in which an initial set of items retrieved by a search algorithm is resorted using a secondary criterion or algorithm to better match user expectations or specific criteria.

ResNet (Residual Network).title: ResNet (Residual Network)
ResNet (Residual Network).content: Type of CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) architecture that introduces residual learning to facilitate the training of much deeper networks by utilizing shortcut connections or skip connections that allow the gradient to bypass some layers.

Residual Connections.title: Residual Connections
Residual Connections.content: DL architecture feature designed to help alleviate the vanishing gradient problem by allowing gradients to flow through a network more effectively.

Retrieval-Based (Model).title: Retrieval-Based (Model)
Retrieval-Based (Model).content: Algorithms that generate responses by selecting them from a predefined set of responses, based on the input they receive.

Reward Model Ensemble.title: Reward Model Ensemble
Reward Model Ensemble.content: Combination of multiple reward models used together to evaluate and guide the learning process of reinforcement learning agents, aiming to improve robustness, accuracy, and generalization of the reward signal.

Rightsizing.title: Rightsizing
Rightsizing.content: Adjusting the computational resources allocated to AI systems to match the workload requirements optimally.

Robustness.title: Robustness
Robustness.content: Ability of an algorithm or model to deliver consistent and accurate results under varying operating conditions and input perturbations.

Roko's Basilisk.title: Roko's Basilisk
Roko's Basilisk.content: Thought experiment proposing that a future all-powerful AI could punish those who did not help bring about its existence.

SAIF (Secure AI Framework).title: SAIF (Secure AI Framework)
SAIF (Secure AI Framework).content: Set of guidelines and best practices developed by Google to enhance the security of AI systems across various applications.

SAM (Segment Anything Model).title: SAM (Segment Anything Model)
SAM (Segment Anything Model).content: AI model designed for high-precision image segmentation, capable of identifying and delineating every object within an image.

SIL (Simulator in the Loop).title: SIL (Simulator in the Loop)
SIL (Simulator in the Loop).content: Methodology in which a simulator is integrated into the control loop of a system, providing a virtual environment for real-time testing and validation of algorithms, control strategies, or system performance.

SIMA (Scalable Instructable Multiworld A.title: SIMA (Scalable Instructable Multiworld Agent)
SIMA (Scalable Instructable Multiworld A.content: AI agent designed to operate across multiple 3D virtual environments, following natural language instructions to accomplish varied tasks.

SLAPA (Self-Learning Agent for Performin.title: SLAPA (Self-Learning Agent for Performing APIs)
SLAPA (Self-Learning Agent for Performin.content: AI agent designed to autonomously learn and interact with APIs to perform tasks more effectively over time.

SNN (Spiking Neural Network).title: SNN (Spiking Neural Network)
SNN (Spiking Neural Network).content: Type of artificial neural network that mimics the way biological neural networks in the brain process information, using spikes of electrical activity to transmit and process information.

SSF (Stochastic Similarity Filter).title: SSF (Stochastic Similarity Filter)
SSF (Stochastic Similarity Filter).content: Moderates GPU usage by skipping processing of similar consecutive input images, thereby improving computational efficiency in real-time image and video generation tasks.

SSL (Self-Supervised Learning).title: SSL (Self-Supervised Learning)
SSL (Self-Supervised Learning).content: Type of ML where the system learns to predict part of its input from other parts, using its own data structure as supervision.

SSM (State-Space Model).title: SSM (State-Space Model)
SSM (State-Space Model).content: Mathematical frameworks used to model dynamic systems by describing their states in space and how these states evolve over time under the influence of inputs, disturbances, and noise.

SVM (Support Vector Machine).title: SVM (Support Vector Machine)
SVM (Support Vector Machine).content: Supervised ML model used primarily for classification and regression tasks, which finds the optimal hyperplane that best separates different classes in the data.

Safety Net.title: Safety Net
Safety Net.content: Measures, policies, and technologies designed to prevent, detect, and mitigate adverse outcomes or ethical issues stemming from AI systems' operation.

Salience.title: Salience
Salience.content: Quality by which certain aspects of a dataset or information stand out as particularly noticeable or important in a given context.

Sample Efficiency.title: Sample Efficiency
Sample Efficiency.content: Ability of a ML model to achieve high performance with a relatively small number of training samples.

Sampling.title: Sampling
Sampling.content: Fundamental technique used to reduce computational cost and simplify data management

Saturation Effect.title: Saturation Effect
Saturation Effect.content: Phenomenon where the performance improvements of a model diminish as the complexity of the model or the amount of training data increases beyond a certain point.

Scaffolding.title: Scaffolding
Scaffolding.content: Method of gradually building up the complexity of tasks or learning environments to help an AI system develop more sophisticated capabilities over time.

Scalable MatMul-free Language Modeling.title: Scalable MatMul-free Language Modeling
Scalable MatMul-free Language Modeling.content: Techniques in natural language processing that avoid matrix multiplication (MatMul) operations to improve scalability and efficiency.

Scalar.title: Scalar
Scalar.content: Single numerical value, typically representing a quantity or magnitude in mathematical or computational models.

Scale Separation.title: Scale Separation
Scale Separation.content: Distinguishing between phenomena or variables that operate on distinctly different magnitudes, time scales, or spatial dimensions.

Scaling Hypothesis.title: Scaling Hypothesis
Scaling Hypothesis.content: Enlarging model size, data, and computational resources can consistently improve task performance up to very large scales.

Search Optimization.title: Search Optimization
Search Optimization.content: Process of enhancing algorithms' ability to efficiently search for the most optimal solution in a potentially vast solution space.

Secure Enclave.title: Secure Enclave
Secure Enclave.content: Hardware-based security feature designed to protect sensitive data by isolating it in a dedicated and secure area of a processor.

Self-Attention.title: Self-Attention
Self-Attention.content: Mechanism in neural networks that allows models to weigh the importance of different parts of the input data differently.

Self-Reasoning Token.title: Self-Reasoning Token
Self-Reasoning Token.content: AI mechanism designed to enhance the planning capabilities of language models by allowing them to anticipate and prepare for future outputs.

Self-Supervised Pretraining.title: Self-Supervised Pretraining
Self-Supervised Pretraining.content: ML approach where a model learns to predict parts of the input data from other parts without requiring labeled data, which is then fine-tuned on downstream tasks.

Semantic Entropy.title: Semantic Entropy
Semantic Entropy.content: Measure of uncertainty or unpredictability in the meaning of a message or data, often considering the context in which the information is used.

Semantic Segmentation.title: Semantic Segmentation
Semantic Segmentation.content: Process of partitioning a digital image into multiple segments (sets of pixels) to simplify its representation into something more meaningful and easier to analyze, where each segment corresponds to different objects or parts of objects.

Semi-Supervised Learning.title: Semi-Supervised Learning
Semi-Supervised Learning.content: ML approach that uses a combination of a small amount of labeled data and a large amount of unlabeled data for training models.

Sequence Model.title: Sequence Model
Sequence Model.content: Model designed to process and predict sequences of data, such as time series, text, or biological sequences.

Sequence Models.title: Sequence Models
Sequence Models.content: Algorithms that predict the next element in a sequence, pivotal for tasks in natural language processing (NLP) such as text generation and translation.

Shared Awareness.title: Shared Awareness
Shared Awareness.content: Collective understanding and perception of information among multiple agents, both human and machine, in a given environment.

Siamese Network.title: Siamese Network
Siamese Network.content: Type of neural network architecture that involves two or more identical subnetworks sharing the same parameters and weights, typically used for tasks like similarity learning and verification.

Silicon-Based Intelligence.title: Silicon-Based Intelligence
Silicon-Based Intelligence.content: Concept of artificial intelligence systems that operate on silicon-based hardware, contrasting with biological, carbon-based forms of intelligence such as humans.

Similarity Search.title: Similarity Search
Similarity Search.content: Method used in data science to identify similar items from a large dataset based on their proximity to a given query item (also known as proximity search).

Simulation.title: Simulation
Simulation.content: Process of creating a digital model of a real-world or theoretical situation to study the behavior and dynamics of systems.

Singularity.title: Singularity
Singularity.content: Hypothetical future point at which technological growth becomes uncontrollable and irreversible, resulting in unforeseeable changes to human civilization.

Situational Models.title: Situational Models
Situational Models.content: Cognitive frameworks that allow AI systems to understand and predict dynamic environments by continuously integrating contextual information.

Slop.title: Slop
Slop.content: Colloquial slang referring to responses generated by  LLMs that may be overly verbose or repetitive, often observed in AI-generated summaries or answers, and sometimes criticized for lacking conciseness or relevance.

Socratic Model.title: Socratic Model
Socratic Model.content: Conversational AI that is designed to engage in dialogue in a manner akin to Socratic questioning, aiming to stimulate critical thinking and draw out ideas and underlying presuppositions.

SoftMax.title: SoftMax
SoftMax.content: Function that converts a vector of numerical values into a vector of probabilities, where the probabilities of each value are proportional to the exponentials of the input numbers.

Solomonoff Induction.title: Solomonoff Induction
Solomonoff Induction.content: Theory of prediction that combines elements of algorithmic information theory and Bayesian inference to create a universal framework for inferring future data from past observations.

Solution Space.title: Solution Space
Solution Space.content: Refers to the set of all possible solutions to a given problem or decision-making scenario.

Sovereign AI.title: Sovereign AI
Sovereign AI.content: Hypothetical form of AI that operates independently with its own autonomy, potentially possessing the ability to make decisions and take actions without human intervention.

Spacetime Patches.title: Spacetime Patches
Spacetime Patches.content: Technique for transforming video data into a format suitable for ML models by breaking down video into temporal and spatial segments.

Sparsability.title: Sparsability
Sparsability.content: Ability of algorithms to effectively handle and process data matrices where most elements are zero (sparse), improving computational efficiency and memory usage.

Sparse Autoencoder.title: Sparse Autoencoder
Sparse Autoencoder.content: Type of neural network designed to learn efficient data representations by enforcing sparsity on the hidden layer activations.

Sparsity.title: Sparsity
Sparsity.content: Technique and principle of having models that utilize minimal data representation and processing, typically through zero or near-zero values.

Spatial Intelligence.title: Spatial Intelligence
Spatial Intelligence.content: Ability of a system to understand, reason, and manipulate spatial relationships and properties within its environment.

Speculative Decoding.title: Speculative Decoding
Speculative Decoding.content: AI technique that generates multiple potential outputs simultaneously to improve efficiency and accuracy in tasks like language modeling and neural network inference.

Speech Processing.title: Speech Processing
Speech Processing.content: Technology that enables computers to recognize, interpret, and generate human speech.

Spillover.title: Spillover
Spillover.content: Unintended consequences or effects that AI systems can have outside of their designed operational contexts.

Stacking.title: Stacking
Stacking.content: ML ensemble technique that combines multiple classification or regression models via a meta-classifier or meta-regressor to improve prediction accuracy.

State Space Model.title: State Space Model
State Space Model.content: Mathematical frameworks used to represent systems that are governed by a set of latent (hidden) variables evolving over time, observed through another set of variables.

Stateful.title: Stateful
Stateful.content: System or application that saves client data from previous sessions to influence and personalize future interactions.

Static Inference.title: Static Inference
Static Inference.content: Process of performing predictions using a pre-trained machine learning model without updating the model parameters during runtime.

Steerability.title: Steerability
Steerability.content: Ability to intentionally manipulate the output of the network in a specific direction by applying predetermined modifications to its inputs or parameters.

Stochastic Parrot.title: Stochastic Parrot
Stochastic Parrot.content: Language models that generate text based on probabilistic predictions, often criticized for parroting information without understanding.

Stochastic.title: Stochastic
Stochastic.content: Systems or processes that are inherently random, involving variables that are subject to chance.

Straight-Through Estimator.title: Straight-Through Estimator
Straight-Through Estimator.content: Technique used in training neural networks to enable the backpropagation of gradients through non-differentiable functions or operations.

Streaming.title: Streaming
Streaming.content: Continuous generation and delivery of text in real-time as the model processes input sequentially.

Structured Data.title: Structured Data
Structured Data.content: Information that is highly organized and formatted in a way that is easily searchable and accessible by computer systems, typically stored in databases.

Structured Generation.title: Structured Generation
Structured Generation.content: Process where outputs are produced in a structured format, often requiring adherence to specific formats or templates, such as tables, graphs, or well-organized textual reports.

Structured Search.title: Structured Search
Structured Search.content: Method of querying and retrieving information from databases and other structured data sources where data is organized in defined types and relationships.

Subsymbolic AI.title: Subsymbolic AI
Subsymbolic AI.content: AI approaches that do not use explicit symbolic representation of knowledge but instead rely on distributed, often neural network-based methods to process and learn from data.

Super Alignment.title: Super Alignment
Super Alignment.content: Theoretical concept in AI, primarily focusing on ensuring that advanced AI systems or AGI align closely with human values and ethics to prevent negative outcomes.

Super Prompting.title: Super Prompting
Super Prompting.content: Method in AI where specific, carefully crafted input prompts are used to guide a model towards generating more accurate or contextually appropriate outputs.

Superintelligence.title: Superintelligence
Superintelligence.content: A form of AI that surpasses the cognitive performance of humans in virtually all domains of interest, including creativity, general wisdom, and problem-solving.

Supervised Classifier.title: Supervised Classifier
Supervised Classifier.content: Algorithm that, given a set of labeled training data, learns to predict the labels of new, unseen data.

Supervised Learning.title: Supervised Learning
Supervised Learning.content: ML approach where models are trained on labeled data to predict outcomes or classify data into categories.

Supervision.title: Supervision
Supervision.content: Use of labeled data to train ML models, guiding the learning process by providing input-output pairs.

Surrogate Objective.title: Surrogate Objective
Surrogate Objective.content: Alternative goal used to approximate or replace a primary objective in optimization problems, especially when the primary objective is difficult to evaluate directly.

Swarm Intelligence.title: Swarm Intelligence
Swarm Intelligence.content: Form of AI inspired by the collective behavior of social insects and animals, used to solve complex problems through decentralized, self-organized systems.

Symbolic AI.title: Symbolic AI
Symbolic AI.content: Also known as "Good Old-Fashioned AI" (GOFAI), involves the manipulation of symbols to represent problems and compute solutions through rules.

Symbolic Regression.title: Symbolic Regression
Symbolic Regression.content: Type of regression analysis that searches for mathematical expressions to best fit a given set of data points.

Symmetry.title: Symmetry
Symmetry.content: Invariances in data or models where certain transformations do not affect the outcomes or predictions.

Synthetic Data Generation.title: Synthetic Data Generation
Synthetic Data Generation.content: Creating artificial data programmatically, often used to train ML models where real data is scarce, sensitive, or biased.

System 1 & System 2.title: System 1 & System 2
System 1 & System 2.content: Two modes of thinking in human cognition: System 1 is fast, automatic, and intuitive, while System 2 is slow, deliberate, and analytical.

System Prompt.title: System Prompt
System Prompt.content: Predefined message or question generated by an AI system to guide or solicit a response from the user.

TCN (Temporal Convolutional Networks).title: TCN (Temporal Convolutional Networks)
TCN (Temporal Convolutional Networks).content: Type of neural network designed to handle sequential data by applying convolutional operations over time.

TEM (Trusted Execution Monitor).title: TEM (Trusted Execution Monitor)
TEM (Trusted Execution Monitor).content: Security component that ensures the integrity and confidentiality of code and data within a computer system by managing and protecting execution environments.

TESCREAL.title: TESCREAL
TESCREAL.content: Seven ideologies: Transhumanism, Extropianism, Singularitarianism, Cosmism, Rationalism, Effective Altruism, and Longtermism. They all focus on using technology to improve people’s lives and they are deeply influential among people working on AGI.

TPU (Tensor Processing Units).title: TPU (Tensor Processing Units)
TPU (Tensor Processing Units).content: Specialized hardware accelerators designed to significantly speed up the calculations required for ML tasks.

TRL (Transfer Reinforcement Learning).title: TRL (Transfer Reinforcement Learning)
TRL (Transfer Reinforcement Learning).content: Subfield of RL focused on leveraging knowledge gained from one or more source tasks to improve learning efficiency and performance in a different, but related, target task.

TRPO (Trust Region Policy Optimization).title: TRPO (Trust Region Policy Optimization)
TRPO (Trust Region Policy Optimization).content: Advanced algorithm used in RL to ensure stable and reliable policy updates by optimizing within a trust region, thus preventing drastic policy changes.

TTFT (Test Time Fine-Tuning).title: TTFT (Test Time Fine-Tuning)
TTFT (Test Time Fine-Tuning).content: Process of adapting a pre-trained model using new data during the testing phase to improve its performance on specific tasks.

TTS (Text-to-Speech).title: TTS (Text-to-Speech)
TTS (Text-to-Speech).content: Converts written text into spoken voice output, enabling computers to read text aloud.

Targeted Adversarial Examples.title: Targeted Adversarial Examples
Targeted Adversarial Examples.content: Inputs intentionally designed to cause a machine learning model to misclassify them into a specific, incorrect category.

Task Environment.title: Task Environment
Task Environment.content: Setting or context within which an intelligent agent operates and attempts to achieve its objectives.

Teacher Committee.title: Teacher Committee
Teacher Committee.content: Group of expert models that collaboratively guide the training process of a student model to improve its performance.

Teacher-Guided Rejection Sampling.title: Teacher-Guided Rejection Sampling
Teacher-Guided Rejection Sampling.content: Advanced ML technique that refines a model by iteratively sampling and accepting data based on evaluations from multiple expert models (teachers).

Temperature.title: Temperature
Temperature.content: Hyperparameter that controls the randomness of predictions by adjusting the probability distribution of the output classes to make the model's predictions more or less deterministic.

Tensor.title: Tensor
Tensor.content: Multi-dimensional array used in mathematics and computer science, serving as a fundamental data structure in neural networks for representing data and parameters.

TensorFlow.title: TensorFlow
TensorFlow.content: Open-source software library for machine learning, developed by Google, used for designing, building, and training deep learning models.

Text to Action.title: Text to Action
Text to Action.content: Process of interpreting and converting written or spoken language into executable actions by a system or application.

Thought Token.title: Thought Token
Thought Token.content: Computational abstraction used in NLP models to represent and manipulate complex ideas or concepts within sequences of text.

Token Speculation Techniques.title: Token Speculation Techniques
Token Speculation Techniques.content: Strategies used in NLP models to predict multiple potential tokens (words or subwords) in parallel, improving the efficiency of text generation.

Token.title: Token
Token.content: Basic unit of data processed in NLP tasks, representing words, characters, or subwords.

Training Cost.title: Training Cost
Training Cost.content: Quantifies the resources required to develop AI models, including computational expenses, energy consumption, and human expertise.

Training Data.title: Training Data
Training Data.content: Dataset used to teach a ML model how to make predictions or perform tasks.

Training.title: Training
Training.content: Process of teaching a ML model to make accurate predictions or decisions, by adjusting its parameters based on data.

Trajectory Generation.title: Trajectory Generation
Trajectory Generation.content: Computational methods for designing the path that an object or agent should follow to reach a destination efficiently and effectively.

Transfer Learning.title: Transfer Learning
Transfer Learning.content: ML method where a model developed for a task is reused as the starting point for a model on a second task, leveraging the knowledge gained from the first task to improve performance on the second.

Transformer.title: Transformer
Transformer.content: Deep learning model architecture designed for handling sequential data, especially effective in natural language processing tasks.

Translational.title: Translational
Translational.content: Process or approach of converting scientific research into practical applications.

Transposed Convolutional Layer.title: Transposed Convolutional Layer
Transposed Convolutional Layer.content: Type of neural network layer that performs the opposite operation of a traditional convolutional layer, effectively upscaling input feature maps to a larger spatial resolution.

Triple.title: Triple
Triple.content: Data structure in the form of a three-part entity consisting of a subject, predicate, and object, commonly used in semantic web technologies and knowledge graphs.

Tunable Parameters.title: Tunable Parameters
Tunable Parameters.content: Variables in an AI model that are adjusted during training to optimize the model's performance on a given task.

Turing Complete.title: Turing Complete
Turing Complete.content: System capable of simulating any Turing machine, thereby performing arbitrary computational operations given enough time and resources.

Turing Test.title: Turing Test
Turing Test.content: Measure of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human.

UTM (Universal Turing Machine).title: UTM (Universal Turing Machine)
UTM (Universal Turing Machine).content: Theoretical construct in computer science that can simulate any other Turing machine's computing process given the appropriate input and its own machine's description.

Uncensored AI.title: Uncensored AI
Uncensored AI.content: AI systems that operate without restrictions on the content they generate or the decisions they make.

Underfitting.title: Underfitting
Underfitting.content: Occurs when a ML model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern of the data it is trained on, resulting in poor performance on both training and testing datasets.

Unhobbling.title: Unhobbling
Unhobbling.content: Process of unlocking latent capabilities in AI models by addressing limitations and inefficiencies, thus significantly enhancing their practical utility.

Universal Learning Algorithms.title: Universal Learning Algorithms
Universal Learning Algorithms.content: Theoretical frameworks aimed at creating systems capable of learning any task to human-level competency, leveraging principles that could allow for generalization across diverse domains.

Universality.title: Universality
Universality.content: Concept that certain computational systems can simulate any other computational system, given the correct inputs and enough time and resources.

Unstructured Data.title: Unstructured Data
Unstructured Data.content: Data that lacks a pre-defined format or organization, making it challenging to collect, process, and analyze using conventional database tools.

Unsupervised Learning.title: Unsupervised Learning
Unsupervised Learning.content: Type of ML where algorithms learn patterns from untagged data, without any guidance on what outcomes to predict.

Unverifyability.title: Unverifyability
Unverifyability.content: Inability to confirm the correctness, validity, or truth of a statement, model, or system, often due to inherent limitations in the verification process or lack of necessary information.

VAE (Variable AutoEncoder).title: VAE (Variable AutoEncoder)
VAE (Variable AutoEncoder).content: Type of generative model that leverages neural networks to encode input data into a latent space and then reconstruct it back to the original input.

VAE (Variational Autoencoders).title: VAE (Variational Autoencoders)
VAE (Variational Autoencoders).content: Class of generative models that use neural networks to encode inputs into a latent space and then decode from this space to reconstruct the input or generate new data that resemble the input data.

VC Dimension (Vapnik-Chervonenkis).title: VC Dimension (Vapnik-Chervonenkis)
VC Dimension (Vapnik-Chervonenkis).content: Measure of the capacity of a statistical classification algorithm, quantifying how complex the model is in terms of its ability to fit varied sets of data.

VLM (Visual Language Model).title: VLM (Visual Language Model)
VLM (Visual Language Model).content: AI models designed to interpret and generate content by integrating visual and textual information, enabling them to perform tasks like image captioning, visual question answering, and more.

VQA (Visual Question Answering).title: VQA (Visual Question Answering)
VQA (Visual Question Answering).content: Field of AI where systems are designed to answer questions about visual content, such as images or videos.

Validation Data.title: Validation Data
Validation Data.content: Subset of data used to assess the performance of a model during the training phase, separate from the training data itself.

Value Matrix.title: Value Matrix
Value Matrix.content: Structured format for organizing and displaying data, often used in machine learning to represent input data and their corresponding outputs or labels.

Vanishing Gradient.title: Vanishing Gradient
Vanishing Gradient.content: Phenomenon in neural networks where gradients of the network's parameters become very small, effectively preventing the weights from changing their values during training.

Vector Database.title: Vector Database
Vector Database.content: Specialized database optimized for storing and querying vectors, which are arrays of numbers representing data in high-dimensional space.

Vectorization.title: Vectorization
Vectorization.content: Process of converting non-numeric data into numeric format so that it can be used by ML algorithms.

Verifier Theory.title: Verifier Theory
Verifier Theory.content: Concept in computational complexity theory that focuses on the role of a verifier in determining the correctness of a solution to a problem within a given complexity class.

ViTs (Vision Transformers).title: ViTs (Vision Transformers)
ViTs (Vision Transformers).content: Class of DL models that apply the transformer architecture, originally designed for natural language processing, to computer vision tasks.

Volumetric AI.title: Volumetric AI
Volumetric AI.content: AI techniques to process, analyze, and generate three-dimensional volumetric data, often used in fields like medical imaging, 3D reconstruction, and virtual reality.

WBE (Whole Brain Emulation).title: WBE (Whole Brain Emulation)
WBE (Whole Brain Emulation).content: Hypothetical process of scanning a biological brain in detail and replicating its state and processes in a computational system to achieve functional and experiential equivalence.

Wait Calculation.title: Wait Calculation
Wait Calculation.content: Assessing whether to proceed with projects immediately or wait for future advancements in AI that could offer significant benefits.

Weight Decay.title: Weight Decay
Weight Decay.content: Regularization technique used in training neural networks to prevent overfitting by penalizing large weights.

Weight.title: Weight
Weight.content: Represents a coefficient for a feature in a model that determines the influence of that feature on the model's predictions.

Word Salad.title: Word Salad
Word Salad.content: Disorganized and nonsensical sequence of words or letters, often making it difficult or impossible to derive coherent meaning from the text.

Word Vector.title: Word Vector
Word Vector.content: Numerical representations of words that capture their meanings, relationships, and context within a language.

World Model.title: World Model
World Model.content: Internal representation that an AI system uses to simulate the environment it operates in, enabling prediction and decision-making based on those simulations.

XAI (Explainable AI).title: XAI (Explainable AI)
XAI (Explainable AI).content: AI systems designed to provide insights into their behavior and decisions, making them transparent and understandable to humans.

Xavier's Initialization.title: Xavier's Initialization
Xavier's Initialization.content: Weight initialization technique designed to keep the variance of the outputs of a neuron approximately equal to the variance of its inputs across layers in a deep neural network.

ZSL (Zero-Shot Learning).title: ZSL (Zero-Shot Learning)
ZSL (Zero-Shot Learning).content: ML technique where a model learns to recognize objects, tasks, or concepts it has never seen during training.

bGPT (Byte-Level Transformer).title: bGPT (Byte-Level Transformer)
bGPT (Byte-Level Transformer).content: Variant of the GPT architecture designed to process data at the byte level rather than at the word or sub-word level, allowing for greater flexibility in handling diverse text types and structures.

k-NN (k-Nearest Neighbors).title: k-NN (k-Nearest Neighbors)
k-NN (k-Nearest Neighbors).content: Simple, non-parametric algorithm used in ML for classification and regression tasks by assigning labels based on the majority vote of the nearest neighbors.

xLSTM.title: xLSTM
xLSTM.content: Extended form of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), integrating enhancements for scalability and efficiency in DL models.
